Examples of Chemical Reaction Networks

Selected Chemical Reaction Networks are used below to demonstrate how the Fisher Information of Chemical Reaction Networks can be computed using Mixture Density Networks.

The Chemical Reaction Networks selected in this study are those presented in the article [FM19].

Production and Degradation Chemical Reaction Network

  • Reactions:

\[\emptyset \xrightarrow{\theta_1} S\]
\[S \xrightarrow{\theta_2} \emptyset\]

  • Propensity functions:

\[\lambda_1(x;\theta) = \theta_1 \quad \lambda_2(x;\theta) = \theta_2 x\]

  • Stoichiometry matrix:

\[\begin{split}\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \end{pmatrix}\end{split}\]

Find code and figures in the notebook CRN_production_degradation.ipynb.

Controlled Production and Degradation Chemical Reaction Network

  • Reactions:

\[\emptyset \xrightarrow{\theta} S\]
\[S \xrightarrow{\xi} \emptyset\]

  • Propensity functions:

\[\lambda_1(x;\theta,\xi) = \theta \quad \lambda_2(x;\theta,\xi) = \xi x\]

  • Stoichiometry matrix:

\[\begin{split}\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \end{pmatrix}\end{split}\]

Find code and figures in the notebook CRN_controlled_production_degradation.ipynb.

Bursting Gene Chemical Reaction Network

  • Reactions:

\[\emptyset \xrightarrow{\theta_1} S_1\]
\[S_1 \xrightarrow{\theta_2} \emptyset\]
\[S_1 \xrightarrow{\theta_3} S_1 + S_2\]
\[S_2 \xrightarrow{\theta_4} \emptyset\]

  • Propensity functions:

\[\begin{split}\begin{array}{lr} \lambda_1(x;\theta) = \theta_1(1-x_1) & \lambda_2(x;\theta) = \theta_2x_1 \\ \lambda_3(x;\theta) = \theta_3 x_1 & \lambda_4(x;\theta) = \theta_4 x_2 \end{array}\end{split}\]

  • Stoichiometry matrix:

\[\begin{split}\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}\end{split}\]

Find code and figures in the notebook CRN_bursting_gene.ipynb.

Controlled Bursting gene Chemical Reaction Network

  • Reactions:

\[\emptyset \xrightarrow{\theta_1} S_1\]
\[S_1 \xrightarrow{\xi} \emptyset\]
\[S_1 \xrightarrow{\theta_2} S_1 + S_2\]
\[S_2 \xrightarrow{\theta_3} \emptyset\]

  • Propensity functions:

\[\lambda_1(x;\theta) = \theta_1 (1-x_1)\]
\[\lambda_2(x;\theta) = \xi x_1\]
\[\lambda_3(x;\theta) = \theta_2 x_1\]
\[\lambda_4(x;\theta) = \theta_3 x_2\]

  • Stoichiometry matrix:

\[\begin{split}\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}\end{split}\]

Find code and figures in the notebook CRN_controlled_bursting_gene.ipynb.

Controlled Toggle switch Chemical Reaction Network

  • Reactions:

\[\emptyset \xrightarrow{\lambda_1} S_1 \quad \emptyset \xrightarrow{\lambda_2} S_2\]
\[S_1 \xrightarrow{\lambda_3} \emptyset \quad S_2 \xrightarrow{\lambda_4} \emptyset\]

  • Propensities

\[\begin{split}\begin{array}{ll} \lambda_1(x;t,\theta,\xi) = \theta_1 + \frac{\theta_3}{1+\theta_6(x_t^2)^{\theta_8}} & \lambda_2(x;t,\theta,\xi) = \theta_2 + \frac{\theta_4}{1+\theta_5(x_t^1)^{\theta_7}} \\ \lambda_3(x;t,\theta,\xi) = \theta_9 x_t^1 & \lambda_4(x;t,\theta,\xi) = \xi x_t^2 \end{array}\end{split}\]

  • Stoichiometry matrix

\[\begin{split}\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}\end{split}\]

Find code and figures in the notebook CRN_controlled_toggle_switch.ipynb.
